abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Earthquake Disability
            Project for Pakistan were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: teams preparing emergency projects
            need to consider how to strike the balance between emergency
            objectives and longer term institution-building approaches
            and policy reforms and whether combining these two
            objectives makes sense. Project preparation should allow
            implementation to begin immediately after effectiveness,
            particularly in emergency operations. Therefore, issues such
            as financial flows, terms of reference for consultancies and
            procurement should be in place by project effectiveness. A
            results framework with measurable indicators needs to be in
            place as well as a functioning monitoring system, including
            arrangements for a timely impact analysis. Project results
            that are immediately relevant to the beneficiaries, their
            families and communities, and the public at large, are an
            effective means of building and expanding support for
            disability programs.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Earthquake
            Disability Project of Pakistan is to improve the quality of
            life of people with disabilities and their families in areas
            affected by the October 8,2005 earthquake, by ensuring
            better mobility, improved physical and mental health,
            increased participation in social and economic life, and
            strengthened empowerment. There are 3 components to the
            project. Component 1 is for provision of services,
            mobilization, and empowerment i.e. ensure delivery of a
            range of services addressing disability and mental health
            needs of Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) and their families
            while at the same time mobilizing and empowering them to
            take action on disability. Component 2 is for capacity
            building for disability rehabilitation--build the capacity
            of the Pakistan Poverty Alleviation Fund (PPAF), its partner
            organizations, as well as service providers and civil
            society organizations to ensure rehabilitation services to
            the PWDs and their families. Component 3 is for project
            management, monitoring, and evaluation--finance the project
            management and support functions undertaken by the PPAF.
